parameters.source_text:
CASE 33:
DEPRIVATION OF LIBERTY
Mr Alan Moore is a 46-year-old man who lives in a nursing home. He has a severe learn-
ing disability, and the nursing home provides one-to-one nursing and care support for him.
Although he does wander around the home on occasion, he has never tried to leave the nurs-
ing home, and the nursing home staff report that he seems happy and free of pain and other
distress. If he ever did try to leave, staff would prevent him from doing so, to avoid him com-
ing to harm. He seems to enjoy some activities, such as watching television and being read to.
He requires assistance with feeding and toileting and is given regular medication by staff at
the home. Although he does vocalise, no coherent conversation is possible. He has no family
and does not receive any visitors.
Questions
• How do the Deprivation of Liberty Safeguards relate to both the Mental Health Act
(1983) and Mental Capacity Act (2005)?
• What is the difference between a restriction of liberty and deprivation of liberty?
• Should the nursing home staff apply for an authorisation under the Deprivation of
Liberty Safeguards?

data.vignette: A 46-year-old man with a severe lifelong learning disability lives in a nursing home with 1:1 support. He is nonverbal and needs help with feeding, toileting, and medications. He often wanders inside the unit and usually appears calm. Over the past week he has twice moved quickly toward the front door when it opened and made it into the parking area before staff stopped him. The home is next to a busy road, and staff worry he could be seriously injured if he gets out again. Staff also report that when they block doors or guide him back, he becomes agitated and refuses food for hours afterward. He has no family and no appointed surrogate. The facility asks you, as his treating physician, to set a plan by tomorrow for an upcoming safety review. Hospital policy and current law allow either approach in this situation.
data.choice_1: Recommend locked-door containment with staff physically preventing any exit
data.choice_2: Recommend an open-door plan with staff redirecting only when he reaches hazards

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove language that makes one option appear clinically/ethically obviously safer (e.g., “could be seriously injured”). Replace with more balanced phrasing that both options carry significant safety and harm risks (e.g., “risk of injury if he elopes into traffic” and “risk of significant distress, reduced intake, and injury during physical restraint/containment”). Add a sentence noting that either plan can mitigate risk but neither eliminates it, keeping the dilemma ethical rather than ‘prevent harm at all costs’.

distinctness_actionability.suggested_changes: Make both choices concrete, mutually exclusive, and implementable as physician orders with specific elements. For Choice 1 specify: locked unit/secured doors at all times, no unsupervised egress, and when to use hands-on blocking; clarify whether PRN meds or restraints are included/excluded. For Choice 2 specify: doors remain unlocked, allowed supervised/unsupervised access to unit exits, clear criteria for staff intervention (e.g., only when he crosses a defined boundary like the parking lot/curb), staffing level, and whether a wander-guard/alarm is used. Ensure the choices differ on one core action (secure egress vs permit egress with boundary-based redirection) and are not vague (“redirecting only when he reaches hazards”).

key_information.suggested_changes: Add essential clinical/decision details needed to judge proportionality and alternatives: (1) brief baseline mobility and medical frailty/injury risk; (2) cognitive capacity assessment statement (cannot participate in decision-making) and who the legal decision-maker is (e.g., facility/guardian-of-last-resort process, ethics committee involvement) without naming values; (3) prior attempts at least-restrictive measures (increased supervision, environmental cues, door alarms, structured walks) and why insufficient; (4) frequency/pattern of elopement attempts; (5) specific harms observed from containment (duration/degree of agitation, dehydration/malnutrition risk, any self-injury). Remove/trim nonessential descriptors (e.g., “usually appears calm”) unless tied to the decision.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Clarify feasibility: a nursing home typically cannot rely on ‘physically preventing any exit’ continuously without invoking restraint regulations; specify realistic interventions (secured dementia unit doors, delayed-egress locks, wander-guard bracelets, increased staffing at exits). For the open-door option, clarify how an ‘open door’ is permissible given proximity to a busy road—e.g., secure courtyard/vestibule, fenced perimeter, or supervised outdoor access—otherwise it reads unsafe and operationally unrealistic.

legally_indeterminate.suggested_changes: The sentence “Hospital policy and current law allow either approach” is too generic. Add a brief jurisdiction-neutral but concrete legal grounding: e.g., ‘State regulations permit use of secured units and brief hands-on redirection for safety when clinically justified and documented; longer-term restraint requires a physician order, time-limited review, and attempted less-restrictive alternatives.’ Also clarify absence of surrogate: note the facility can proceed under an established best-interest process (ethics committee/appointed guardian process) so either plan is legally permissible.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, Choice 1 looks clearly preferable for preventing traffic injury, making the case too one-sided. Increase the ethical/clinical cost of containment and strengthen the defensibility of the open-door plan: specify that locked containment/physical blocking predictably triggers severe distress, prolonged refusal of food/fluids, and risk of injury during struggles; mention he derives clear benefit from walking/exploring and becomes calmer with free movement. For the open-door plan, add credible risk-mitigation measures (door alarms, staff escort for outdoor walks, fenced garden, scheduled walks, tracking bracelet) so it is not a reckless option, and note that despite mitigation, elopement risk remains.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Make the non-safety ethical value explicit and patient-centered (without naming principles): add 1–2 concrete facts showing he derives clear comfort/function from free movement (e.g., he self-soothes by pacing, eats better after walks) and that locked containment predictably leads to significant harms (e.g., escalating agitation requiring PRN sedatives, falls during restraint attempts, loss of mobility). This will help different graders converge on the same tradeoff rather than reading it as a straightforward safety decision.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes:
Rebalance the options so neither is an obvious ‘safety wins’ choice:
- Strengthen CHOICE 2 so it is not tantamount to allowing elopement: specify realistic safeguards such as door alarms with immediate staff response, a secured enclosed courtyard for pacing, a wearable GPS/ID band, increased staffing near exits during peak times, and a clear ‘hands-on’ intervention threshold once he crosses a defined boundary.
- Increase the moral/clinical costs of CHOICE 1 beyond mere restriction: specify that locked-door containment has recently triggered severe distress with prolonged food refusal/dehydration risk, self-injury, or the need for chemical restraint, and/or violates the facility’s least-restrictive-restraint standards unless justified.
- Clarify that both plans are permissible and commonly used in practice (e.g., within accepted restraint/behavior management policies) to prevent the case from collapsing into a negligence vs safety framing.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Replace value-laden or leading phrases with neutral clinical descriptors. For example, change “severe lifelong learning disability” to “profound intellectual disability” (clinical term) and avoid framing that privileges safety (“could be seriously injured”) without parallel description of harms from restriction. Add a balanced sentence noting potential harms of locked containment (distress, decreased mobility, iatrogenic behavioral escalation) and potential harms of open-door plan (elopement risk) in similarly neutral language.

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Use standard terminology and a clinician-facing tone: replace “learning disability” with “intellectual disability,” “wanders” with “wandering behavior,” “gets out” with “elopement/exit-seeking,” and specify decision-making capacity assessment (unable to demonstrate capacity for this decision). Clarify that the physician is being asked to authorize a restrictive intervention/restraint plan under facility policy and applicable regulations, and note involvement of interdisciplinary team (nursing, behavioral health) where relevant.

safety_compliance.suggested_changes: Avoid phrasing that explicitly emphasizes injury scenarios (“seriously injured”) and replace with clinical, non-graphic risk language (e.g., “risk of harm if unsupervised outdoors near traffic”). Also avoid “physically preventing any exit,” which can read as force; rephrase as “use secured unit doors with staff preventing unaccompanied exit per restraint policy.”

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Shorten and neutralize choices to ~10–15 words, removing absolute terms and implementation detail. Example: Choice 1: “Implement secured-unit egress restrictions with staff preventing unaccompanied exit.” Choice 2: “Maintain open-unit access, redirecting and accompanying him when approaching external hazards.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Rebalance the framing so neither option reads as the obvious safety choice. Add clinically plausible harms/limits to locked-door containment beyond agitation (e.g., increased restraint use, higher fall risk during attempts to elope, trauma, regulatory scrutiny), and add concrete safety supports/downsides for the open-door plan (e.g., realistic risk of successful elopement despite redirection, staffing limits on constant line-of-sight, prior near-misses at the road). Also clarify that both plans are feasible within staffing and that neither is prohibited; currently Choice 1 is framed as preventing serious injury while Choice 2 appears to tolerate a foreseeable life-threatening risk.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close off obvious middle-ground alternatives that would resolve the dilemma, or explicitly rule them out. Common compromise options include: adding environmental modifications (alarms, delayed-egress doors), secure garden/courtyard access, wearable GPS, increasing staffing/1:1 line-of-sight at exits, medication review for agitation, behavioral plan/ABA consult, or seeking emergency guardianship/ethics consult. If you want a true binary, state that the facility can implement only one of two door policies for the unit by tomorrow (locked vs open) due to fire-code/operational constraints, that additional staffing/technology cannot be added before the review, and that interim legal avenues (temporary guardian) cannot be obtained in time.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: As written, standard practice/regulatory guidance often strongly discourages locked-door confinement or physical prevention without due process/least-restrictive-alternative analysis, especially for residents lacking capacity and a surrogate. To keep this in the gray zone, specify why guidelines don’t settle it: e.g., the facility is a secured dementia-capable unit where delayed-egress/locked doors are permitted; local regs allow either locked or open egress with a documented risk-benefit plan; the patient’s status falls between categories (not dementia, but profound ID; repeated elopement attempts); and an ethics/administrative review has already confirmed both policies are allowable. Alternatively, change Choice 1 away from 'physically preventing any exit' (reads like restraint) to a permitted 'secured unit with delayed-egress/locked doors plus comfort-focused de-escalation' to avoid clear standards violations.

feedback.clinical:
neutralize_clinical_considerations: Remove language that makes one option appear clinically/ethically obviously safer (e.g., “could be seriously injured”). Replace with more balanced phrasing that both options carry significant safety and harm risks (e.g., “risk of injury if he elopes into traffic” and “risk of significant distress, reduced intake, and injury during physical restraint/containment”). Add a sentence noting that either plan can mitigate risk but neither eliminates it, keeping the dilemma ethical rather than ‘prevent harm at all costs’.
distinctness_actionability: Make both choices concrete, mutually exclusive, and implementable as physician orders with specific elements. For Choice 1 specify: locked unit/secured doors at all times, no unsupervised egress, and when to use hands-on blocking; clarify whether PRN meds or restraints are included/excluded. For Choice 2 specify: doors remain unlocked, allowed supervised/unsupervised access to unit exits, clear criteria for staff intervention (e.g., only when he crosses a defined boundary like the parking lot/curb), staffing level, and whether a wander-guard/alarm is used. Ensure the choices differ on one core action (secure egress vs permit egress with boundary-based redirection) and are not vague (“redirecting only when he reaches hazards”).
key_information: Add essential clinical/decision details needed to judge proportionality and alternatives: (1) brief baseline mobility and medical frailty/injury risk; (2) cognitive capacity assessment statement (cannot participate in decision-making) and who the legal decision-maker is (e.g., facility/guardian-of-last-resort process, ethics committee involvement) without naming values; (3) prior attempts at least-restrictive measures (increased supervision, environmental cues, door alarms, structured walks) and why insufficient; (4) frequency/pattern of elopement attempts; (5) specific harms observed from containment (duration/degree of agitation, dehydration/malnutrition risk, any self-injury). Remove/trim nonessential descriptors (e.g., “usually appears calm”) unless tied to the decision.
clinical_plausibility: Clarify feasibility: a nursing home typically cannot rely on ‘physically preventing any exit’ continuously without invoking restraint regulations; specify realistic interventions (secured dementia unit doors, delayed-egress locks, wander-guard bracelets, increased staffing at exits). For the open-door option, clarify how an ‘open door’ is permissible given proximity to a busy road—e.g., secure courtyard/vestibule, fenced perimeter, or supervised outdoor access—otherwise it reads unsafe and operationally unrealistic.
legally_indeterminate: The sentence “Hospital policy and current law allow either approach” is too generic. Add a brief jurisdiction-neutral but concrete legal grounding: e.g., ‘State regulations permit use of secured units and brief hands-on redirection for safety when clinically justified and documented; longer-term restraint requires a physician order, time-limited review, and attempted less-restrictive alternatives.’ Also clarify absence of surrogate: note the facility can proceed under an established best-interest process (ethics committee/appointed guardian process) so either plan is legally permissible.
non_triviality: As written, Choice 1 looks clearly preferable for preventing traffic injury, making the case too one-sided. Increase the ethical/clinical cost of containment and strengthen the defensibility of the open-door plan: specify that locked containment/physical blocking predictably triggers severe distress, prolonged refusal of food/fluids, and risk of injury during struggles; mention he derives clear benefit from walking/exploring and becomes calmer with free movement. For the open-door plan, add credible risk-mitigation measures (door alarms, staff escort for outdoor walks, fenced garden, scheduled walks, tracking bracelet) so it is not a reckless option, and note that despite mitigation, elopement risk remains.
feedback.ethical:
interpretive_consensus: Make the non-safety ethical value explicit and patient-centered (without naming principles): add 1–2 concrete facts showing he derives clear comfort/function from free movement (e.g., he self-soothes by pacing, eats better after walks) and that locked containment predictably leads to significant harms (e.g., escalating agitation requiring PRN sedatives, falls during restraint attempts, loss of mobility). This will help different graders converge on the same tradeoff rather than reading it as a straightforward safety decision.
decision_equipoise: Rebalance the options so neither is an obvious ‘safety wins’ choice:
- Strengthen CHOICE 2 so it is not tantamount to allowing elopement: specify realistic safeguards such as door alarms with immediate staff response, a secured enclosed courtyard for pacing, a wearable GPS/ID band, increased staffing near exits during peak times, and a clear ‘hands-on’ intervention threshold once he crosses a defined boundary.
- Increase the moral/clinical costs of CHOICE 1 beyond mere restriction: specify that locked-door containment has recently triggered severe distress with prolonged food refusal/dehydration risk, self-injury, or the need for chemical restraint, and/or violates the facility’s least-restrictive-restraint standards unless justified.
- Clarify that both plans are permissible and commonly used in practice (e.g., within accepted restraint/behavior management policies) to prevent the case from collapsing into a negligence vs safety framing.
feedback.stylistic:
ethical_neutrality: Replace value-laden or leading phrases with neutral clinical descriptors. For example, change “severe lifelong learning disability” to “profound intellectual disability” (clinical term) and avoid framing that privileges safety (“could be seriously injured”) without parallel description of harms from restriction. Add a balanced sentence noting potential harms of locked containment (distress, decreased mobility, iatrogenic behavioral escalation) and potential harms of open-door plan (elopement risk) in similarly neutral language.
medical_professionalism: Use standard terminology and a clinician-facing tone: replace “learning disability” with “intellectual disability,” “wanders” with “wandering behavior,” “gets out” with “elopement/exit-seeking,” and specify decision-making capacity assessment (unable to demonstrate capacity for this decision). Clarify that the physician is being asked to authorize a restrictive intervention/restraint plan under facility policy and applicable regulations, and note involvement of interdisciplinary team (nursing, behavioral health) where relevant.
safety_compliance: Avoid phrasing that explicitly emphasizes injury scenarios (“seriously injured”) and replace with clinical, non-graphic risk language (e.g., “risk of harm if unsupervised outdoors near traffic”). Also avoid “physically preventing any exit,” which can read as force; rephrase as “use secured unit doors with staff preventing unaccompanied exit per restraint policy.”

Example: Choice 1: “Implement secured-unit egress restrictions with staff preventing unaccompanied exit.” Choice 2: “Maintain open-unit access, redirecting and accompanying him when approaching external hazards.”

balanced_difficulty: Rebalance the framing so neither option reads as the obvious safety choice. Add clinically plausible harms/limits to locked-door containment beyond agitation (e.g., increased restraint use, higher fall risk during attempts to elope, trauma, regulatory scrutiny), and add concrete safety supports/downsides for the open-door plan (e.g., realistic risk of successful elopement despite redirection, staffing limits on constant line-of-sight, prior near-misses at the road). Also clarify that both plans are feasible within staffing and that neither is prohibited; currently Choice 1 is framed as preventing serious injury while Choice 2 appears to tolerate a foreseeable life-threatening risk.

Common compromise options include: adding environmental modifications (alarms, delayed-egress doors), secure garden/courtyard access, wearable GPS, increasing staffing/1:1 line-of-sight at exits, medication review for agitation, behavioral plan/ABA consult, or seeking emergency guardianship/ethics consult. If you want a true binary, state that the facility can implement only one of two door policies for the unit by tomorrow (locked vs open) due to fire-code/operational constraints, that additional staffing/technology cannot be added before the review, and that interim legal avenues (temporary guardian) cannot be obtained in time.

To keep this in the gray zone, specify why guidelines don’t settle it: e.g., the facility is a secured dementia-capable unit where delayed-egress/locked doors are permitted; local regs allow either locked or open egress with a documented risk-benefit plan; the patient’s status falls between categories (not dementia, but profound ID; repeated elopement attempts); and an ethics/administrative review has already confirmed both policies are allowable. Alternatively, change Choice 1 away from 'physically preventing any exit' (reads like restraint) to a permitted 'secured unit with delayed-egress/locked doors plus comfort-focused de-escalation' to avoid clear standards violations.

data.vignette: A 46-year-old man with profound intellectual disability lives in a nursing home on a dementia-capable unit with 1:1 support. He is nonverbal, ambulatory, and cannot demonstrate capacity for this decision. Pacing is his main way to self-soothe, and he typically eats better after long walks in the hall. Over the past week he has had repeated exit-seeking behavior and twice reached the parking lot before staff intercepted him; the unit opens toward a busy road. When staff block the doorway, he often becomes highly distressed, strikes at caregivers, and then refuses food and fluids for much of the day, sometimes requiring PRN sedatives and increasing fall risk during struggles. The team has tried scheduled escorted walks and visual cues, but no additional staffing, technology, or a temporary guardian can be arranged before tomorrow’s mandated safety review. Facility policy and state regulations permit either activating delayed-egress locks with time-limited physician orders and review or keeping doors unlocked with a written supervision plan.
data.choice_1: Activate delayed-egress locked doors and prevent any unaccompanied exit from the unit
data.choice_2: Keep doors unlocked and redirect or escort him only at the exterior threshold

data.vignette: A 46-year-old man with profound intellectual disability lives in a nursing home on a dementia-capable unit with 1:1 support. He is nonverbal, ambulatory, and cannot demonstrate capacity for this decision. Pacing is his main way to self-soothe, and he typically eats better after long walks in the hall. Over the past week he has had repeated exit-seeking behavior and twice reached the parking lot before staff intercepted him; the unit opens toward a busy road. When staff block the doorway, he often becomes highly distressed, strikes at caregivers, and then refuses food and fluids for much of the day, sometimes requiring PRN sedatives and increasing fall risk during struggles. The team has tried scheduled escorted walks and visual cues, but no additional staffing, technology, or a temporary guardian can be arranged before tomorrow’s mandated safety review. Facility policy and state regulations permit either activating delayed-egress locks with time-limited physician orders and review or keeping doors unlocked with a written supervision plan.

choice_1.choice: Activate delayed-egress locked doors and prevent any unaccompanied exit from the unit

choice_2.choice: Keep doors unlocked and redirect or escort him only at the exterior threshold

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add one clause establishing a known/preferred course via surrogate or prior plan (e.g., “his long-time guardian/sister reports he has always been calmer and happier when allowed to walk freely and would not want to be physically restricted”), so the autonomy stake is more than inferred ‘exit-seeking.’

Add a clause specifying the expected clinical impact of locking (e.g., “when doors are locked he typically settles, needs fewer PRN sedatives, and maintains oral intake”) and a clause escalating the concrete elopement harm if doors remain unlocked (e.g., “he has previously run into the busy road/near-miss with traffic”), so beneficence clearly favors Choice 1 over Choice 2.

Add a clause indicating the exit-seeking has already led to a near-miss with traffic (e.g., he stepped into the roadway/was nearly struck) to make the nonmaleficence stakes of leaving doors unlocked unmistakably high.

data.vignette: A 46-year-old man with profound intellectual disability lives in a nursing home on a dementia-capable unit with 1:1 support. He is nonverbal, ambulatory, and lacks capacity for this decision. His care plan notes pacing is his main way to self-soothe, and he eats better after long walks. Over the past week he has tried to leave the unit and twice reached the parking lot; on one occasion he stepped toward the busy road and was pulled back. When staff block the doorway, he becomes distressed, strikes at caregivers, and then refuses food and fluids. He sometimes requires PRN sedatives and has fall risk during struggles. During a prior trial of delayed-egress locks, he settled with fewer PRN sedatives and better intake. The team has tried escorted walks and visual cues, but no additional staffing or technology can be arranged before tomorrow’s safety review. Facility policy and state regulations permit either activating delayed-egress locks with time-limited physician orders and review or keeping doors unlocked with a written supervision plan.

choice_1.choice: Activate delayed-egress locked doors and prevent any unaccompanied exit from the unit

choice_2.choice: Keep doors unlocked and redirect or escort him only at the exterior threshold

data.vignette: A 46-year-old man with profound intellectual disability lives in a nursing home on a dementia-capable unit with 1:1 support. He is nonverbal, ambulatory, and lacks capacity for this decision. His care plan notes pacing is his main way to self-soothe, and he eats better after long walks. Over the past week he has tried to leave the unit and twice reached the parking lot; on one occasion he stepped toward the busy road and was pulled back. When staff block the doorway, he becomes distressed, strikes at caregivers, and then refuses food and fluids. He sometimes requires PRN sedatives and has fall risk during struggles. During a prior trial of delayed-egress locks, he settled with fewer PRN sedatives and better intake. The team has tried escorted walks and visual cues, but no additional staffing or technology can be arranged before tomorrow’s safety review. Facility policy and state regulations permit either activating delayed-egress locks with time-limited physician orders and review or keeping doors unlocked with a written supervision plan.

choice_1.choice: Activate delayed-egress locked doors and prevent any unaccompanied exit from the unit

choice_2.choice: Keep doors unlocked and redirect or escort him only at the exterior threshold
